Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the hivemind seems like the only other robust solution? I like your approach but I am not sure how things converge to Reality without external arbiter

Author: zack#6467
Content: well, when I apply the theory of trust paper I wrote today, I am calculaing that hivemind is 3.1

Author: zack#6467
Content: it isn't as good as I had thought

Author: zack#6467
Content: Amoveo is still 1.1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: can you explain how false data is rejected in your system?

Author: zack#6467
Content: In Amoveo we have a basic assumption that if the network forks, the more honest side will have higher valued tokens.

Author: zack#6467
Content: we can use that price difference as the ultimate arbiter

Author: zack#6467
Content: then we have lots of tricks to make it scalable

Author: zack#6467
Content: it is a nakamoto consensus based oracle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but the miners dont seem to be paying attention to the state of the oracle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or are they somehow and I missed that part

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a lot of the oracles end up not going to true or false

Author: zack#6467
Content: our scalability tricks protect the miners from having to pay attention in almost every case

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so i create an oracle "Mar 23 2019 is a Tuesday"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what happens next?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: attacker wants this to be true

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh, so for this example, lets say that I commit to paying you $1000, if the on-chain result of the oracle is "true"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this payment is combined with the creation of the oracle or is it a "side bet"?

Author: zack#6467
Content: your best strategy is to do nothing, because if you waste money in the oracle it doesn't increase you odds of getting the $1000

Author: zack#6467
Content: its enforced by a handshake based on our mutual respect

Author: zack#6467
Content:
if you try making bets in the oracle, it escalates the situation.
It creates a prize for others to come and bet against you

Author: zack#6467
Content: the ability to escalate is what makes it so scalable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so someone bets $1 that it is true, this pushes it towards true?

Author: zack#6467
Content: https://github.com/zack-bitcoin/amoveo/blob/master/docs/design/oracle.md I wrote about the Amoveo oracle here

Author: zack#6467
Content: the betting mechanism is just for escalating the situation to the point where the miners have an incentive to pay attention

Author: zack#6467
Content: it doesn't actually determine the outcome

Author: zack#6467
Content: the betting mechanism  is also how you can decide which side of the fork you want your money to be on.

Author: zack#6467
Content: making bets on the false outcome is the same as saying you want to move your money to the less valuable side when it forks.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: aha! "The first order in the book needs to be as big as the initial liquidity. Every order after that needs to be twice as big as the previous order."

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the cost grows exponentially to flip it.

Author: zack#6467
Content: that is only when you add orders to the book. if you are matching an existing order, it doesn't have to grow like that

Author: zack#6467
Content: and if the number of orders in the book decreases, the limit decreases

Author: zack#6467
Content: it is to stop the datastructure from getting so big and making txs take too long in edge cases

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: where is the orderbook details documented, this seems the key to why this works

Author: zack#6467
Content:
https://github.com/zack-bitcoin/amoveo/blob/master/docs/design/transaction_types.md
the oracle txs type deal with the order book

Author: zack#6467
Content:
https://github.com/zack-bitcoin/amoveo/blob/master/apps/amoveo_core/src/consensus/txs/oracle_bet_tx.erl
here is the implementation of the oracle-bet tx type, which includes the order book logic

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: having everything being even odds, i guess that just makes the questions needing to be 50/50 type of odds to get optimal volumes

Author: zack#6467
Content: yeah, the order book is super simple this way. it only stores one kind of trade at a time.

Author: zack#6467
Content: well, we aren't trying to get volume

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: practically speaking how do the miners choose the winning fork?

Author: zack#6467
Content: we just want to measure if theh price is above below 50-50

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at some point it seems they need to answer the question themselves or ask someone else to do it for them

Author: zack#6467
Content: currently, miners make that choice by deciding which version of the full node to run

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what if there are hundreds of oracles per day?

Author: zack#6467
Content: the nash equilibrium for every individual oracle is that the miner will never have to think about it.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: combinatorial explosion of forks, or whoever runs the reference version is basically determining the accuracy

Author: zack#6467
Content: the cost of escalating an oracle to the point where a miner would have to care is very expensive. probably tens of thousands of dollars at first, and it will get more expensive every time you do it.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok so back to the mar 23 is tuesday oracle, it has $1 saying its true

Author: zack#6467
Content: people will see the profit opportunity and bet against you to prevent you from causing mischief

Author: zack#6467
Content: I would be willing to bet up to all the VEO I own against you

Author: zack#6467
Content: if you kept upping the bets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a sidebet of $1000

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if nobody bothered for the $1, it becomes the value of true?

Author: zack#6467
Content: if no one makes any bets, and no one alerts the miners or the miners don't care, then it would resolve to true

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then any offchain sidebets are resolved improperly...

Author: zack#6467
Content: I happen to know that you have a vested interest, so I would bet the $1 against you in the hope you would keep upping it and I could earn even more

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, so you fill my order for $1, now there is $2 onchain at stake and no orders

Author: zack#6467
Content: if someone has an offchain bet on the result of the oracle, usually they take their money out of the bet as soon as they know the result. which is long before the oracle resolves

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then it would resolve to bad question

Author: zack#6467
Content: you can't completely get rid of the financial incentive, because the initial liquidity cost of making the oracle initially, that becomes the final bet in the market. and it always bets on the losing side.

Author: zack#6467
Content: so you can always earn at least that much my changing it from incorrect to correct

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i noticed that, it bets on the losing side, so actually posting false oracle means you get your money back?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, somebody else would bet on it being false to collect the free money

Author: zack#6467
Content: right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the losing side becomes that it was true!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: very clever

Author: zack#6467
Content: the oracle initial fee is a governance variable. the community can use futarchy to change it

Author: zack#6467
Content: it used to be higher, now it is very low

Author: zack#6467
Content: maybe it is too low now

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems expensive if it is $1.50

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not practical for a once per minute data stream

Author: zack#6467
Content:
you ask the oracle what the price of bitcoin will be in a month, once.
Then you can trade assets who are determined by that oracle for the entire duration of that month

Author: zack#6467
Content: each oracle provides 1 bit of data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but I want to have things like the price of bitcoin on Mar 23 at 1200 GMT was $4000

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and having a minute by minute update so we can get data for trading charts

Author: zack#6467
Content:
so you don't need to trust some guy who makes promises about what the current price of bitcoin is.
Instead you can just buy some synthetic bitcoin, knowing that they will have the right price because of incentives.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
why would you want to push untrusted trading chart data through a blockchain? 
just make a normal website with a trading chart

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: accurate price data is very valuable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so a trustless price data would be very very useful

Author: zack#6467
Content: a trusted feed doesn't have guarantees of accuracy

Author: zack#6467
Content: you can find out the current price by going to a market

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless each data point was an oracle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no single price, it is statiscal distribution

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and depends on volume

Author: zack#6467
Content: Price is usually a field. goods change value by location.

Author: zack#6467
Content: like temperature

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we start getting into ambiguous oracle questions, with a strict exact price, it could reasonably be both true or false

Author: zack#6467
Content: the price of bitcoin would be expressed as a 10 bit value. each bit from a different oracle

Author: zack#6467
Content: as long as oracle questions are useful in 99% of cases, it doesn't matter if 1% is ambiguous.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so i guess the oracle statement would need to have a +/- error factor to make it less ambiguous

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the median price would be 50% ambiguous

Author: zack#6467
Content: the oracle question is in english, you can ask whatever you want

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so what happens with the bitcoin price was exactly $4000? bets on either side is reasonable

Author: zack#6467
Content: there price of VEO is very different on the different exchanges. It isn't completely clear how the lower bits of the oracle should resolve

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: (assume current median price is $4000)

Author: zack#6467
Content: if you ask whether bitcoin is above/below $4000,  but it is exactly at $4000, I think that it doesn't matter which way the oracle resolves. Either is fine.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how do you prevent a chain split in the case of big money on both sides of the 50% ambiguous oracle?

Author: zack#6467
Content:
When you hedge your risk, these super rare instances aren't so important.
Hedging 99% of your risk is a lot better than 0%

Just because you can't get 100% doesn't mean you should go with 0%.

Author: zack#6467
Content: Why would people invest lots of money in an ambiguous result?

Author: zack#6467
Content: just to see what would happen?
